items.content:
Tule.slo:

Kerndoel 34 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, Mens en Samenleving

De leerlingen leren zorg te dragen voor de lichamelijke en psychologische gezondheid van henzelf en anderen.

Kerndoel 37 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, Mens en Samenleving

De leerlingen leren zich te gedragen vanuit respect voor algemeen aanvaarde waarden en normen.

IPC:

MP3 thema: Feelings - Emotions

Mens en Samenleving 3.1
De leerlingen weten dat ze bij het vak Mens en Samenleving dingen leren over het leven als lid van een groep.

Mens en Samenleving 3.3
De leerlingen zijn bekend met belangrijke internationale organisaties.

Mens en Samenleving 3.4
De leerlingen zijn bekend met belangrijke tradities, vieringen en manieren van leven in Nederland en in andere landen waar ze misschien een band mee hebben.

Mens en Samenleving 3.5
De leerlingen begrijpen hun eigen verantwoordelijkheden binnen de groepen waartoe ze behoren.

Mens en Samenleving 3.6
De leerlingen begrijpen de verantwoordelijkheden van anderen binnen deze groepen en in de bredere gemeenschap.

Mens en Samenleving 3.8
De leerlingen begrijpen dat het gedrag van individuen van invloed is op het leven van anderen.

Mens en Samenleving 3.9
De leerlingen zijn in staat om de aard van groepen en sociale instituties en de invloed die deze hebben op het leven van mensen te onderzoeken.

De leerlingen leren over gevoelens en emoties, de klassenregels worden besproken, de verschillende manieren van pesten worden behandeld en de kinderen bespreken wat hen blij maakt

Activiteit 1 = De leerlingen bespreken de klassenregels en de leerlingen maken er een poster van.

Activiteit 2 = De vocabulaire over gevoelens en emoties wordt behandeld. De activiteit is te gebruiken bij de kennisoogst. De leerlingen spelen een spel en doen een groepsactiviteit waarbij ze spreken over gevoelens a.d.h.v. verschillende scenario's.

Activiteit 3 = De leerlingen leren over de verschillende manieren van pesten en maken een worksheet.

Activiteit 4 = Gespreksactiviteit over wat de kinderen blij maakt en ze bedenken wat daarbij het meest belangrijk voor henzelf is.

Game: Loop game

Challenge: To complete the loop within a set time

Functional language:
How do you feel when you...., I feel....

Vocabulary:
Smile, happy, frown, worried, blush, embarassed, miserable, sad, interesting, bored, tired, temper, angry, excited, alone, lonely, fear, scared, clearly, confused, funny, amused, hurt, malicious, arrogant.

Instructions:
- All pupils being dealt a set of cards with a question and an answer to a different question
- Begin with any pupil reading out their question, the pupil with the corresponding correct answer is required to read it out. That pupil then reads their question for another pupil to answer.
- A loop game is constructed so that the sequence ensures that all questions and answers must be used.
- In a loop game the sequence always arrives back at the first question.

Variation
Short loops can be used as competitive team activities (which team can complete the loop first?) or small group activities. This helps to ensure that every pupil is fully involved in the whole activity.

For team activities, divide a class of 28-30 into three teams for a 10-unit loop, four teams for an 8-unit loop or five teams for a 6-unit loop. Each member of the team is given one section of the loop, then the team has to stand up and physically rearrange themselves (holding their section facing outwards) into a circle so that the sections match to form the loop (You may have to give one pupil two consecutive units of the loop if your numbers do not divide evenly.)

Resources:

Time needed: 45 mins

Kerndoel: 34, 37 IPC: 3.1, 3.5, 3.6, 3.8

Description:
Open the prowise presentation (1). Discuss with the pupils why do you think that we need rules? Ask the pupils to work with their talking partner and think about the class rules they have. Share the class rules in English with the pupils and introduce the functional language "I can remember to....." and "We will remember to ....". Print out page 7(Our Class Rules) and ask the pupils to work with their talking partner and practise saying the rules. Ask the pupils to design a poster about their class rules.

Functional language:
I can remember to, We will remember to, Share and take turns, Stand in line quietly, Listen carefully, Hold scissors pointing down, Stay in our seat, Be polite, Put things away, Use our indoor voice, Put our hand up, Keep our hands and feet to ourselves, Walk not run, Help others.

Vocabulary:
Share, quietly, scissors, polite, seat, voice, ourselves, others, remember, stand

Resources:

1

Time needed: 90 mins

Kerndoel: 34, 37 IPC: 3.1, 3.5, 3.6, 3.8

Description:
This is an activity that you can do in the knowledge harvest to introduce and develop some vocabulary about feelings before commencing the unit. Previous to commencing this activity you will need to print out sheet (2) cut up the cards and stick them in different places outside your classroom. Firstly ask the pupils what words they already know in English to express their feelings. Ask the pupils to work with their talking partner and then share their ideas with the class. Next each pair will need a piece of paper and a pen. Partner 1 has to go out of the classroom and find a word (that you have previously stuck up in different places) and remember it while partner 2 stays in the classroom. Partner 1 then needs to report back to partner 2 what the word is and partner 2 has to write it down. They then swop over so that partner 2 then goes out to find a word and partner 1 stays in the classroom. This is a game to see which team (partners) will be the first to get all the words. You need to decide how many words you want the pupils to find and differentiate according to the level of your class. You can then give points to the winner, second, third etc . When all teams are back in the classroom it is important that you then go over the meanings of the words with the pupils. Prowise presentation (3) can be shown to revise the vocabulary and go over the meanings of the words. Worksheets (4) and (5) can also be used to revise the vocabulary. Show the prowise presentation (1) to the pupils and explain that there are a number of different scenarios. You may need to read the scenarios out with the pupils depending on the level of their English. Print out the different scenarios and the feelings words (2), then ask the pupils to work in a group and decide how they think each person feels. It is important that you introduce the functional language and encourage the pupils to use this when they are working in their group. At the end of the lesson each group can then report back to the class what they thought.

Functional language:
How do you think ..........felt?, I think.........felt........., What do you think?, It is your turn to read.

Vocabulary:
Unhappy, grumpy, cheerful, lonely, tired, worried, nervous, tired, embarrassed, excited, sleepy, shy, funny, upset, happy, sad, angry, scared, excited, jealous, disgusted, proud, anxious, annoyed, grateful, cross, pleased frustrated

Resources:

1 2 2

3 4 5

Time needed: 45 mins

Kerndoel: 34, 37 IPC: 3.1, 3.3, 3.5, 3.6, 3.8, 3.9

Description:
Ask the pupils three questions.What do you think bullying is?, What does it feel like to be bullied?, What does the bully feel like?The pupils may not have the English vocabulary to answer these questions so differentiate according to your class and allow pupils to answer in Dutch if needs be. Discuss with the pupils that there are 5 different types of bullying.Verbal, physical, emotional, racial/sexual and online/phone. Show the prowise presentation (1) with the pupils and ask them in groups to discuss whether the different scenerios are bullying or not. Pupils to use the functional language "I think this is bullying" and "I don't think this is bullying". To extend the more able pupils you can ask them to give a reason why. Hand out the bullying sheet to the pupils and ask them to work with their talking partner to decide what type of bullying the different scenerios are. Pupils to use the functional language when sharing their answers with the rest of the class.

Functional language:
I think this is bullying, I don't think this is bullying, I think....... is physical bullying, I think....... is emotional bullying, I think....... is verbal bullying, I think......... is online/phone bullying, I think ............is racial/sexual bullying.

Vocabulary:
Whispering, kicking, stamping, throwing, threatening, poking, slapping, beating, punching, choking, rumours, intimidating, teasing

Resources:

1 2 3

Time needed: 45 mins

Kerndoel: 34, 37 IPC: 3.1, 3.4, 3.8

Description:
Start the activity by opening the prowise presentation (1) and showing the pupils the video clip of people talking about what makes them happy. Ask the pupils to work with their talking partner and write down what makes them happy. Ask the pupils to share their responses with another talking partner pair before you share some of the ideas with the whole class and discuss. Hand out a set of cards (2) to each pupils and ask them to sort them out in a diamond ranking activity (3) from the most important to the least important with regards to what makes them happy. Remind the pupils that there is no correct answer it is all how they feel. Ask the pupils to go and tell someone else in the class how they decided to sort the cards. Encourage the pupils to use the functional language when discussing their results, see the prowise presentation. Discuss the results with the class. Are there any similarities? Why did pupils choose........ as the most important and ........ as the least important? Encourage pupils to use the functional language ' My most important is .........' and 'My least important is........'. End the activity with the pupils singing the song 'Happy'.

Functional language:
Most important, least important, What is most important for you? What is least important for you? Why did you put this here? I put this here because.......'I agree this is important, I disagree this is important, Being with familiy, Being alone, Helping others, Trying new experiences.

Vocabulary:
Important, most, least, agree, disagree, alone, experiences, family, friends, computer, games, sport, holiday, parties, shopping, listening, and playing.

Resources:

1 2 3
